{{other uses|Cubango (disambiguation){{!}}Cubango}} {{Infobox river | name = Okavango | name_native = | name_native_lang = | name_other = | name_etymology = | image = Namibia Okavango 2.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Okavango in Kavango, Namibia | map = Okavango River Basin map.png | map_size = | map_caption = Okavango river basin map | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_size = | pushpin_map_caption= | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[Angola]], [[Namibia]], [[Botswana]] | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = | subdivision_type4 = | subdivision_name4 = | subdivision_type5 = | subdivision_name5 = | length = {{convert|1700|km|mi|abbr=on}} | width_min = | width_avg = | width_max = | depth_min = | depth_avg = | depth_max = | discharge1_location= | discharge1_min = {{convert|350|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_avg = {{convert|475|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_max = {{convert|1000|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} | source1 = | source1_location = | source1_coordinates= | source1_elevation = | mouth = | mouth_location = [[Moremi Game Reserve]], [[Botswana]] | mouth_coordinates = | mouth_elevation = | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|530000|km2|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = | tributaries_right = | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }} The '''Okavango River''' (formerly spelled Okovango or Okovanggo) is a [[river]] in southwest [[Africa]]. It is the fourth-longest river system in southern Africa, running southeastward for {{convert|1,600|km|mi|abbr=on}}. It begins in [[Angola]], where it is known by the Portuguese name '''Rio Cubango'''. Further south, it forms part of the border between Angola and [[Namibia]], and then flows into [[Botswana]], draining into the [[Moremi Game Reserve]]. Before it enters Botswana, the river drops 4 m in a series of rapids known as Popa Falls, visible when the river is low, as during the dry season.Siyabona Africa Travel (Pty) Ltd, "Popa Falls | Okavango River | Botswana" webpage: [http://www.travel.za.net/africa_popa_falls.html TravelZA-PopaFalls] Discharging to an [[endorheic basin]], the Okavango does not have an outlet to the sea. Instead, it empties into a swamp in the [[Kalahari Desert]], known as the [[Okavango Delta]] or Okavango Alluvial Fan. In the rainy season, an outflow to the [[Boteti River]] in turn seasonally discharges to the [[Makgadikgadi Pan]]s, which features an expansive area of rainy-season [[wetland]] where tens of thousands of [[flamingo]]s congregate each summer.C. Michael Hogan (2008) ''Makgadikgadi'', The Megalithic Portal, ed. A. Burnham [http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=22373&mode=&order=0] Part of the river's flow fills [[Lake Ngami]]. Noted for its [[wildlife]], the Okavango area contains Botswana's Moremi Game Reserve. During colder periods in Earth's history, a part of the Kalahari was a massive lake, known as [[Lake Makgadikgadi]]. In this time, the Okavango would have been one of its largest tributaries.
[[File:Cuito and Okavango (2018).jpg|thumb|Confluence of Cuito (from top) and Okavango (flowing from left to right) (2018)
{{Coord|18|01|40|S| 020|47|31|E|display=inline|dim:10000}}]]
== Water conflict == Both Namibia and Botswana experience drought, and as a result, concerns have been expressed about possible conflict over use of the river's water. Namibia has built a water canal, measuring about 300 km long, and has proposed a project to build a 250-km pipeline to divert water from the river into Namibia to help relieve the drought.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hWrEcl2ydzEC&pg=PA294|title=Resource Politics in Sub-Saharan Africa|last=Basedau|first=Matthias|date=2005-01-01|publisher=GIGA-Hamburg|year=|isbn=9783928049917|location=|pages=294|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Z3ilzosWx4wC&pg=PA96|title=Management of Transboundary Rivers and Lakes|last=Varis|first=Olli|last2=Tortajada|first2=Cecilia|last3=Biswas|first3=Asit K.|date=2008-03-15|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|year=|isbn=9783540749288|location=|pages=96|language=en}} Botswana, however, uses the Okavango Delta for both tourism income and a water source. The Department of Water Affairs in Botswana has submitted that 97% of the water in the river is lost through evaporation, so the country cannot afford to lose any extra water. Namibia, in turn, has argued that it will only divert half of one percent of the river's flow, and that it is entitled to any water that flows through its country. To deal with such issues, in September 1994, Angola, Namibia, and Botswana signed an agreement to form the [http://www.okacom.org Permanent Okavango River Basin Water Commission], to provide advice to the three countries about the best ways to share the Okavango River's resources. == Flood == [[File:Popafälle (2018).jpg|thumb|Popa Falls (2018)]] Every wet season, Angola receives three times more rainfall than Botswana, discharging a higher than usual flow into the Okavango, turning swathes of outlying desert into a huge wetland. Although the summer rains fall in Angola in January, they take a whole month to travel the first 1,000 km of the Okavango River, and then they take a further four months to [[filtration|filter]] through the plants and numerous channels of the final 250 km of the delta. As a result, the flood is at its biggest sometime between June and August, during Botswana’s dry winter months. The delta then swells to three times its permanent size, attracting animals from miles around and creating one of Africa’s greatest concentrations of [[wildlife]]. At its widest point in a big flood year, the seasonal [[swamp]] stretches to 150 km across from east to west; one of the factors that leads to the ever-changing nature of the delta is the flatness of the area. If one were to take a cross section of the delta at its widest point, one would find that the height variation from the mean over that 150 km is less than 2 m, which means that a minor sand deposition can cause major changes.http://blog.africabespoke.com/okavango-delta-part-2/ Okavango River Flooding In very wet years, a part of the river's flow may extend along the Magweggana River (actually a northeastern distributary of the Okavango Delta) and enter the [[Zambezi River]], bypassing the Kalahari. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/okavango-river-the-flow-of-a-lifeline/oclc/55607774&referer=brief_results Okavango River: the Flow of a Lifeline] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070602013353/http://www.jerome-guillaumot.com/gallery/2351150 Safari in the Delta] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120813015647/http://www.waterandnature.org/en/resources/publications/thematic-collection/facts-figures/watersheds-world Map of the Okavango River basin at Water Resources eAtlas] * [http://www.rhinoafrica.com/destinations/okavango_delta/map_of_okavango_delta/ Map of the Okavango Delta at RhinoAfrica] * [http://www.okacom.org/ OKACOM Homepage] * [http://epsmo.iwlearn.org/ OKACOM's EPSMO Project] * [http://www.africabespoke.com/travel-destinations/southern-africa/botswana/ Botswana destinations] * [http://www.galenfrysinger.com/okavango_river.htm] Okavango river {{Rivers of Angola}} {{coord|18|57|43|S| 22|29|04|E|region:BW_type:river|display=title}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Rivers of Angola]] [[Category:Rivers of Namibia]] [[Category:Rivers of Botswana]] [[Category:International rivers of Africa]] [[Category:Kalahari Desert]] [[Category:Angola–Namibia border]] [[Category:Water resource conflicts]] [[Category:Border rivers]]

'''Online Business Licensing Service''' ('''OBLS''') is a one-stop portal for businessmen to apply for all the required [[Government of Singapore|Singapore government]] licences in a single online transaction. The service routes all applications to various government agency for processing.
The [[World Bank]] has ranked [[Singapore]] first in the [[Ease of Doing Business Index]]. The OBLS system contributes to this ranking.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
==Background of the Service== OBLS was first conceived by the Pro-Enterprise Panel, a high level joint public-private sector panel chaired by the Head of Civil Service, Singapore. The panel received a lot of business feedback to cut red-tape in making it easy to start businesses in Singapore.
Small and medium enterprises were the main target of the OBLS project due to their large number. This group were generally unhappy with the costs and complexities of the licensing process.
OBLS was also a key project under the Singapore e-Government Action Plan II.
==Scope== 260 business licences that are issued by more than 30 government agencies in Singapore are found in the OBLS. More than 80% of start-up businesses in Singapore are served by OBLS without having to visit Government counters. The system also offers Update, Renewal and Termination services for 65 licences.
==Features== # Search for the licences that they may need # Apply for multiple licences at once using the integrated form # Update particulars on existing licence # Renew existing licences that are expiring soon # Terminate licences that are no longer required # Pay for multiple licences via one consolidated transaction
==Achievements== As of 1 October 2005, the average license processing time for all new applications including those not handled by OBLS was reduced from 21 to 8 days as a result of the reengineering exercise and OBLS implementation. 85 licenses were processed in less than a week. Of these, 43 were processed in less than three days.<ref>Case Studies: Cross-Agency Integrated e-Services – Online Business Licensing Service [http://www.ecquaria.com/customers/case_studies_obls.html]</ref> Based on the cost-benefit analysis done at 31 Dec 2006, businesses have benefited from the OBLS project with an estimated cost savings of US$27 million (since the pilot launch in Jan 2004 ). The cost savings were derived from the reduction in the amount of licence fees, reduction in the processing time of licences and the time-savings by businessmen who now do not need to travel and queue up physically and complete multiple application forms that ask for similar information. Businessman have given the OBLS an 80% positive feedback rating.
==Awards== OBLS won the following awards:<ref>[https://licences.business.gov.sg/SHINE/sop/WebPageHandler?p=OASIS&pn=Info&ss=PopupAwards Awards:OBLS has gained recognition for its services]</ref> * 2005 [[United Nations Public Service Awards]]<ref>[http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/un/unpan020145.pdf LIST OF WINNERS FOR THE 2005 UNITED NATIONS PUBLIC SERVICE AWARDS] </ref> * ZDNet Asia Smart50 Award 2006 * 2007 Computerworld Honors Program * MIS Asia IT Excellence Award 2007
==OBLS for other Countries== It is widely recognised that countries that have invested in infocomm as a key enabler to transform their business environment have reaped tremendous benefits. The success of OBLS in Singapore has caught the attention of countries also keen to promote a world-class pro-enterprise business environment. Singapore, through the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA), has been actively sharing their experience on government e-Transformation.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * https://licences.business.gov.sg/ * http://www2.egov.gov.sg/online_newsletter/issue18/OBLS.htm {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}}

'''Party subsidies''' or '''public funding of political parties''' are [[subsidy|subsidies]] paid by the government directly to a [[political party]] to fund some or all of its political activities. Most democracies (in one way or the other) provide cash grants (state aid) from taxpayers' money, the general revenue fund, for party activity. Such funds may cover routine or campaign costs incurred by the party. Among the established democracies the United States (the [[Presidential Fund]] takes money from the general fund of the US government only after authorized by a statement indicated upon a taxpayers tax return), Switzerland and India are the most notable exceptions. Party subsidies can be relatively small (as in the U.K.) or quite generous (as in Sweden, Israel and Japan).
The recipients of public support (in cash or kind) are party organizations, parliamentary groups (party caucuses) and/ or candidates for public office (parliament or presidency). In combination with rules that enforce fair access to and fair distribution of state aid among the players of the political game, government funding for political activity can be an acceptable policy option for democratic polities. The allocation of party subsidies follows general rules for access to and distribution of such grant, for example access for all parties represented in the national parliament and distribution in proportion to the number of seats held in the current parliament, or in proportion to the number of votes polled in the most recent election. Many subsidy schemes are linked to reporting and disclosure obligations for the recipient parties.
Rare instruments of party subsidies are [[matching funds]] and [[tax credits]]. Matching funds are granted to a political competitor who has proven to a government authority that he or she solicited small individual donations. Tax credits can be deducted by the taxpayer from tax liability because some part of a political donation is treated like an advance payment on tax. Because matching funds and tax credits depend on financial contributions by individual citizens such support is more compatible with a participatory concept of democracy than flat grants, which do not require specific efforts by the fundraising parties (or candidates).
In many democracies public funding for political parties was introduced after scandals, which revealed [[political corruption]] or illegal funding, had become public knowledge. In other countries, the rising costs of political competition stimulated the spread of party subsidies (government funding).
Although the mainstream opinion is in favour of party subsidies now, they are still disputed.<ref>Cf. Pinto-Duschinsky: 'it's their party, and we pay for it', in: ''The Sunday Times'', October 22, 2006 - http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article608907.ece.</ref> Supporters of party subsidies argue that directly providing the campaign funds reduces [[political corruption]], as parties do not need to raise "money with an opinion/ strings attached".
==History== In 1954 Costa Rica and Uruguay were the first countries to introduce party subsidies. They were followed by Puerto Rico (a U.S. territory in the Caribbean) in 1957 and [[Party finance in Germany|West Germany]] in 1959. In Quebec (1963), a Canadian province, [[Party finance in Sweden|Sweden]] (1965), Finland (1967) and Israel (1969) parties received such support rather early.<ref>Alexander, Herbert E. (ed.): ''Comparative Political Finance in the 1980s'', Cambridge, UK et al.: Cambridge University Press, 1989, pp. 14/15.</ref> Since the 1970s, party subsidies were introduced by Norway (1970), [[Federal political financing in Canada|Canada]] and Italy (1974), Austria (1975), the U.S. (1976), [[Political donations in Australia|Australia]] (1984), Denmark (1986), France (1988), Belgium (1989), [[Political funding in Japan|Japan]] (1994), Ireland (1997), [[Party funding in the Netherlands|the Netherlands]] (1999), the U.K. (2000) and New Zealand (2010). Nowadays among the established democracies only India and Switzerland stand out as exceptions to the rule.<ref>Casas-Zamora, Kevin: ''Paying for Democracy. Political Finance and State Funding of Parties'', Colchester, UK: ECPR, 2005, pp.30/31.</ref> By now it is also used in Greece, Portugal, Spain and other more recently established democracies in Europe and Latin America.
In Italy, following the abolition of the state financing of political parties, clear examples are initiatives of Prime Minister [[Matteo Renzi]] who organized on 6 and 7 November 2014, two fund-raising dinners, held respectively in [[Rome]] and [[Milan]], for the Italian [[Democratic Party (Italy)|Democratic Party]], which included, among the dinner guests, In Italy however political parties keep receiving money even if the state financing was abolished, [[James Pallotta]].<ref>{{cite news|url = http://therword.info/renzi-at-democratic-party-fund-raising-event-we-need-your-ideas-not-just-one-thousand-euros/ |title = Renzi at Democratic Party Fund-raising Event: "We need your ideas, not just one thousand Euros"|work = [[TheRword News]]|accessdate = 13 November 2014}}</ref>
==Criticism== Critics of party subsidies argue that party subsidies:<ref>For a brief compilation of pros and cons see Casas-Zamora; ''Paying for democracy. Polirtical finance and state funding for parties''. Colchester, UK: ECPR Press, pp. 28/29.</ref>
* make parties less accountable to their supporters, because they have less of a need to solicit donations, * petrify the party system and thereby lock the democratic process, because subsidies are distributed based on prior election results and not on current voter attitudes,<ref>The argument to the contrary was already published in: Alexander, Herbert E. (ed.): ''Political Finance in the 1980s'', Cambridge UK et al: Cambridge University Press, 1989, pp. 248/249.</ref> * make the formation or electoral participation of new parties more difficult, because such parties do not receive public funding right from the start and occasionally private funding is prohibited.<ref>The Greens (''Die Grünen'') and the Pirate Party (''PIRATEN'') in Germany are examples to the contrary after they had survived their very first, unsuccessful election bids. Cf. external link to the distribution of party subsidies in that country.</ref>
== See also == * [[Political finance]] * [[Political party funding]] * [[Political funding in Australia]] * [[Party funding in Austria]] * [[Federal political financing in Canada]] * [[Party finance in Germany]] * [[Political funding in Ireland]] * [[Political funding in Japan]] * [[Party funding in the Netherlands]] * [[Political funding in New Zealand]] * [[Party finance in Sweden]]
== Further reading == * Alexander, Herbert, 'Khayyam Zev Paltiel and the Theories of Public Financing', in: Gagnon, Alain/ Tanguay, Brian (eds.), ''Democracy with Justice. Essays in Honour of Khayyam Zev Paltiel'', Ottawa: Carleton University Press, 1992, pp. 355–369. {{ISBN|0-88629-155-0}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141217150955/http://www.idea.int/political-finance/question.cfm?id=270] International IDEA, Political Finance Database, Question 19: Direct party subsidies. * http://aceproject.org/epic-en/CDMap?question=PC12 * [http://www.vaalit.fi/15482.htm Subsidies to the parties], Ministry of Justice, Finland (brief explanation in English). * [http://www.bundestag.de/htdocs_e/bundestag/function/party_funding_05.pdf General deskription of subsidies to parties in Germany by the Parliamentary administration.]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.bundestag.de/htdocs_e/bundestag/function/party_funding_01.pdf Distribution of subsidies to individual parties in Germany by the Parliamentary administration.]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.parlement.com/id/vhnnmt713ozz/subsidies_politieke_partijen.htm]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Information by the Dutch parliament on Party subsidies

page.title: Political purges during and after the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Tiananmen Square protests of 1989]]; added [[Category:1989 Tiananmen Square protests]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|The Tiananmen Square protests of 1989]] were a turning point for many Chinese officials, who were subjected to a purge that started after June 4, 1989. The purge covered top-level government figures down to local officials, and included General Secretary [[Zhao Ziyang]] and his associates.<ref>{{cite book|title=Burying Mao: Chinese Politics in the Age of Deng Xiaoping|last1=Baum|first1=Richard|date=1994|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=New Jersey|pages=314}}</ref> The purge took the form of a massive ideological campaign that lasted 18 months. At least 4 million party members (a tenth of the total) were under some sort of investigation.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People’s Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited|last=Lim|first=Louisa|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2014|isbn=|location=New York|pages=49}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Prisoner of the State|last=Zhao|first=Ziyang|publisher=The University of Michigan Press|year=1996|isbn=|location=Ann Arbor|pages=29}}</ref> The government stated that the purge was undertaken for the purpose of “resolutely getting rid of hostile elements, antiparty elements, and corrupt elements" as well as "dealing strictly with those inside the party serious tendencies toward bourgeois liberalization”<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The Aftermath of the 1989 Tiananmen Crisis in Mainland China|last=Lin|first=Bih-jaw|publisher=Westview Press|year=1992|isbn=|location=San Francisco|pages=116}}</ref> and purify the party.<ref name=":1" />
Party members who joined the demonstration before the declaration of martial law had to write thousand-word accounts to prove their loyalty, but ultimately their loyalty would be determined by the party. Only the members whose loyalty had been proved could re-register their party memberships.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The Legacy of Tiananmen|last=Miles|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=28}}</ref> Those who expressed the desire to resign to protest the crackdown were not allowed resignation, instead, the party would expel them.<ref name=":2" />
== Nationwide Purge == The initial stage of the purge only targeted approximately 250 liberal-minded leading cadres who played an active role in supporting the student protest.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Burying Mao|last=Baum|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=316}}</ref> However, when the party hardliners tried to expand the purge within the party, they found it difficult to isolate a “small handful” of officials.<ref name=":3" /> Although an investigation was launched against all ranks of officials across the country after the event,<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Legacy of Tiananmen|last=Miles|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=30}}</ref> the result did not match the [[Communist Party of China|Chinese Communist Party]]’s expectation.
Over 800,000 party members and cadres had supported the student movement, but according to the Fourteenth Party Congress in October 1992, only 1,179 party cadres were punished and a total of 13,254 party cadres were required to undergo party discipline.<ref name=":3" /> The major reasons for the failure of the re-registration campaign were: First, local officials tried to protect and cover for each other; second, many party members were angry about the military crackdown and considered the campaign as a tool to test their loyalty; third, many members believed that they had been wronged and that CCP betrayed its principles.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Legacy of Tiananmen|last=Miles|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Liusi neibu riji (六四内部日记)|last=Chaoqi|first=Lu|publisher=Zhuoyue wenhua chubanshe|year=2006|isbn=|location=Hong Kong|pages=187–188}}</ref>
Nevertheless, though the campaign did not match the CCP’s goal, many members had been purged. In the name of an anticorruption campaign that started in spring 1990, 79,000 party members were expelled in 1990, and by October 1992 the cumulative total had increased to 154,289.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Burying Mao|last=Baum|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=317}}</ref> Although it is not clear how many party members were expelled solely because of the political purge because the party never publicly revealed the number,<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Legacy of Tiananmen|last=Miles|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=29}}</ref> it is hard to deny the purge’s connection with the protest.
== Purge of Top Officials == [[File:Bao Tong from VOA.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Bao Tong]] in 2014. Tong was a high level party official punished for his reformist views.]]
Zhao Ziyang was the General Secretary of CCP in 1989, who was the most powerful political figure during that time. He was one of the first party officials who lost political power during the purge. Zhao and [[Hu Qili]] voted against enacting the martial law in response to the protests during the Politburo Central Committee meeting on May 17, 1989. [[Li Peng]] and [[Yao Yilin]] voted the opposite, and [[Qiao Shi]] remained neutral. There was no clear majority in the vote until [[Deng Xiaoping]] and Yang [[Yang Shangkun|Shangkun]] were suddenly added; they both sided with Li Peng.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Prisoner of the State: The Secret Journal of Zhao Ziyang|last=Zhao|first=Ziyang|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2009|isbn=|location=New York|pages=29–30}}</ref>
After this meeting, Zhao Ziyang refused to participate in implementing martial law in any aspect.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Prisoner of the State|last=Zhao|first=Ziyang|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=30–31}}</ref> He was called a counterrevolutionary during an informal meeting in Deng Xiaoping’s house on May 20 because of his support for the protesting students and his anti-party decision attitude. In the same meeting, Deng announced the removal of Zhao from the position of General Secretary.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Prisoner of the State|last=Zhao|first=Ziyang|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=35}}</ref>
Zhao tried to protest the legitimacy of Deng’s decision by claiming “it cannot be considered legal to have made such a decision when two members of the PSC had not even been notified”.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Prisoner of the State|last=Zhao|first=Ziyang|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=35–36}}</ref> Zhao could not accept the decision from Deng, however, it did not change the result. On June 24, Zhao was officially condemned for supporting the turmoil (动乱) and splitting (分裂) the party. From the party’s perspective, Zhao was deemed responsible for his alleged contribution to the turmoil, and he, as a result, lost all his posts.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=|title="Fourth Meeting of the Party’s Thirteenth Central Committee (党的十三届中央委员会召开第四次全会),"|last=|first=|date=June 25, 1989|work=People’s Daily|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|page=A1}}</ref> Moreover, Zhao lost his freedom of mobility ever since.<ref name=":0" /> Zhao became the first victim of the political struggle or purge.
[[Hu Qili]] was a member of the [[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Politburo Central Committee]], and he voted against issuing martial law with Zhao Ziyang on May 17.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Prisoner of the State|last=Zhao|first=Ziyang|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=29}}</ref> Besides his vote on May 17, Hu also publicly declared the necessity for reform. From May 11 to May 13, Hu invited leaders from the press in Beijing and shared his opinion on the student movement. He emphasized before the press the need to have democratic reforms based on the law. More importantly, he claimed the press had the duty to increase CCP and government transparency.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=|title="Hu Qili and other government officials dialogue with the press in Beijing (胡启立等同首都新闻界对话),"|last=|first=|date=May 14, 1989|work=People’s Daily|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|page=A1}}</ref> However, on June 24, Hu Qili’s positions in both the [[Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China|Politburo Standing Committee]] (常委) and the [[Politburo of the Communist Party of China|Politburo]] (委员) were removed.<ref name=":4" />
[[Bao Tong]] was another casualty of the purge. He was a secretary to the Politburo and Zhao’s right-hand man. Bao was at the centre of the political reforms in the late 1980s and during the student movement in 1989. He was also a critical figure in the Zhao’s government.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People’s Republic of Amnesia|last=Lim|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=162–163}}</ref> When Zhao decided to support the student movement and refused to consider the student movement as an unrest, Bao drafted his speeches in meetings.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People’s Republic of Amnesia|last=Lim|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=163}}</ref> When Zhao lost in the political struggle on May 17, Bao Tong was quickly arrested. Although before his arrest, Bao tried to use citizen’s right and party members’ right and duty to protect himself, he quickly realised that “these things [were] probably not enough to protect [him]”.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People’s Republic of Amnesia|last=Lim|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=165}}</ref>
On May 28, 1989, Bao was imprisoned in [[Qincheng Prison]], which holds the country’s most important political criminals, without due process.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People’s Republic of Amnesia|last=Lim|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=158}}</ref> Bao received his sentence on July 21, 1992. Bao was sentenced to seven years of imprisonment and deprived of political rights for two years. He was charged with leaking government classified information by warning the demonstrators at Tiananmen Square that martial law was about to be imposed.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People’s Republic of Amnesia|last=Lim|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=157–158}}</ref> He was also convicted for promoting anti-revolutionary propaganda.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title="Bao Tong Case Final Sentence (鲍彤一案终审裁决),"|last=|first=|date=August 7, 1992|work=People’s Daily|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> As Zhao’s associate, Bao was also removed from his political positions.
[[Yan Mingfu]] and [[Rui Xingwen]] were both secretaries to the Politburo during the student movement. Yan and Rui attended the meeting with the press in Beijing on May 13. Hu Qili was the leading cadre in the meeting, Yan and Rui also expressed positive opinions about the student movement and the necessity of government reform.<ref name=":5" /> On May 15, Yan Mingfu affirmed students’ patriotism and their enthusiasm on promoting democracy when he had a conversion with more than 50 student leaders. He and Li Tieying both publicly claimed the student movement was mostly positive. They also stated that the party and government needed to reform in terms of decision-making, democratization, anti-corruption and more social problems.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title="Li Tieying and Yan Mingfu Have a Conversion with Some Students" (李铁映阎明复同首都部分学生对话),"|last=|first=|date=May 14, 1989|work=People’s Daily|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|page=A1}}</ref> For these activities, the CCP Thirteen through its Central Committee Meeting, removed Yan Mingfu and Rui Xingwen from their posts effective June 24.<ref name=":4" />

'''Queering Paradigms''' ('''QP''') refers to an informal network, a series of conferences and a book series. QP originally started as a colloquium in February 2008 to celebrate [[LGBT History Month]] at [[Canterbury Christ Church University]]. This colloquium was in part a protest against the university's stance to prevent civil partnership ceremonies from taking place on campus.<ref name="interviewB_en">{{cite web|title=Interview with Professor Scherer in English|url=http://www.alab.org.br/images/stories/alab/alab%20interview%20b%20scherer_final.pdf|work=Associação de Linguística Aplicada do Brasil|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref><ref name="IntRel">Scherer, B.{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms: From Individual Resistance to Global-Local Impact|url=http://www.e-ir.info/2015/02/23/queering-paradigms-from-individual-resistance-to-global-local-impact/}}E-International Relations (2015)</ref> The conferences have since taken place in [[Canterbury]] (UK), [[Brisbane]] (Australia), [[Oneonta, New York|Oneonta]] (US), [[Rio de Janeiro]] (Brazil), [[Quito]] (Ecuador) and, again in the South of England ([[Winchester]] and Canterbury). The book series has five volumes so far.<ref>Book series [http://secure.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=series&pk=41777&concordeid=QP Queering Paradigms] Peter Lang</ref>
==Queering Paradigms I (February 2009)== [[File:Queering Paradigms 1 Canterbury Flyer 2009.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Poster for the first QP conference|Flyer for QP 1 in Canterbury]] The first official Queering Paradigms conference was organised in February 2009<ref name="QP">{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms|url=https://www.canterbury.ac.uk/arts-and-humanities/school-of-humanities/religion-philosophy-and-ethics/research/queering-paradigms.aspx|work=Canterbury Christ Church University|accessdate=January 17, 2016}}</ref> in Canterbury by B Scherer, a professor of comparative religion, gender and sexuality at Canterbury Christ Church University.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prof B Scherer|url=https://www.canterbury.ac.uk/arts-and-humanities/school-of-humanities/Staff/Profile.aspx?staff=bb106075f34e0f0a|work=Canterbury Christ Church University|accessdate=January 17, 2016}}</ref> The book resulting from this conference was published by [[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang Oxford]] in 2010 and was edited by Scherer.<ref name="QP1">Scherer, B (ed.),[http://secure.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=52870 Queering Paradigms] Peter Lang (2010)</ref>
==Queering Paradigms II (April 2010)== This conference took place at the [[Queensland University of Technology]]<ref name="QP"/><ref>{{cite web|title=QP2 webpage|url=http://www.news.qut.edu.au/cgi-bin/WebObjects/News.woa/wa/goNewsPage?newsEventID=31965|work=Queensland University of Technology|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> and was organised by Sharon Hayes,<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr Sharon Hayes|url=http://staff.qut.edu.au/staff/hayess/|work=Queensland University of Technology|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> Matthew Ball<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Matthew Ball|url=http://staff.qut.edu.au/staff/ballmj/|work=Queensland University of Technology|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> and Angela Dwyer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Angela Dwyer|url=http://staff.qut.edu.au/staff/dwyerae/|work=Queensland University of Technology|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> Former High Court Justice [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]] gave a keynote speech,<ref>{{cite web|last=Kirby|first=Michael|title=Gay marriage must be allowed: Justice Kirby|url=http://www.news.qut.edu.au/cgi-bin/WebObjects/News.woa/wa/goNewsPage?newsEventID=32004|work=QUT|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> which was widely commented upon in Australian newspapers.<ref>{{cite web|last=ABC News, 8 April 2010|title=Kirby slams government inaction on same-sex marriage|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-04-08/kirby-slams-government-inaction-on-same-sex/2595582|work=ABC News|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=The Age, 8 April 2010|title=Gay Ricky worth 10 judges, says Kirby|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/gay-ricky-worth-10-judges-says-kirby-20100408-rtv9.html|work=The Age|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Berry|first=Petrina|title=Former judge calls on government to come out on gay unions|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/former-judge-calls-on-government-to-come-out-on-gay-unions-20100408-rttz.html|work=The Brisbane Times, 8 April 2010|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jeffrey|first=James|title=Crazy about Rick|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/opinion/strewth/crazy-about-rick/story-e6frgdk6-1225851574672|work=The Australian, 9 April 2010|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}</ref> Also the second book was published by Peter Lang and was edited by Scherer and Ball.<ref name="QP2">Scherer, B and Ball, M (Eds.),[http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=59632&cid=564 Queering Paradigms II] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614083509/http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=59632&cid=564 |date=June 14, 2012 }}: Interrogating Agendas, Peter Lang (2011)</ref>
==Queering Paradigms III (April 2011)== QP 3 was organised at [[SUNY]], Oneonta, by Kathleen O'Mara and Betty Wambui.<ref name="QP"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms III|url=http://www.oneonta.edu/academics/qp3/|work=SUNY Oneanta|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>Liz Morrish, [http://www.oneontauup.org/assets/files/Sentinel/UUP%20May%202011%20Sentinel.pdf "Queering Paradigms III". ''The Sentinel'']{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 11 (9) 2011, pp. 20-22.</ref> O'Mara and Liz Morrish edited the book.<ref name="QP3">O'Mara and Morrish, L (Eds.),[http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=72160&cid=5&concordeid=430939 Queering Paradigms III] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723041006/http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=72160&cid=5&concordeid=430939 |date=July 23, 2015 }}: Queer Impact and Practices, Peter Lang (2013)</ref>
==Queering Paradigms IV (July 2012)== [[File:QPconferenceorganisers Rio2012.jpg|thumb|right|alt=QP conference organisers at the QP 4 conference in Rio de Janeiro|QP organisers]] QP 4 took place in Rio de Janeiro and was organised by Rodrigo Borba, Elizabeth Lewis, Branca Fabrício and Diana Pinto,<ref name="QP"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms 4|url=http://www.alab.org.br/eventosalab/queering/pag.php?view=article&id=98|work=Associação de Linguística Aplicada do Brasil|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> who are also the editors of the QP 4 book(s): one book in English was published in 2014<ref name="QP4">Lewis, Borba, Fabrício and Pinto (Eds..),[http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=82724&cid=860&concordeid=431823 Queering Paradigms IV] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009060043/http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=82724&cid=860&concordeid=431823 |date=October 9, 2014 }}: South-North Dialogues on Queer Epistemologies, Embodiments and Activisms, Peter Lang (2014)</ref> and another volume has been planned as a bilingual book in Portuguese and Spanish.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paper QP4|url=http://www.alab.org.br/eventosalab/queering/pag.php?view=article&id=123|work=Associação de Linguística Aplicada do Brasil|accessdate=July 16, 2013}}</ref>
==Queering Paradigms V (February 2014)== QP 5 took place in Quito, Ecuador in February 2014.<ref name="QP"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms 5|url=http://www.flacsoandes.org/coloquioqueer|work=FLACSO Ecuador}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CfP Queering Paradigms V|url=http://h-net.msu.edu/cgi-bin/logbrowse.pl?trx=vx&list=H-Histsex&month=1306&week=b&msg=kUSR2N0PoXYuf9/Y7kLmvg|work=H-Net}}</ref><ref>[http://www.hoy.com.ec/noticias-ecuador/las-diversidades-sociales-y-sexuales-aun-son-incomodas-601395.html#.UxEI5zuDlR8.facebook "Las diversidades sociales y sexuales aún son incómodas"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413143846/http://www.hoy.com.ec/noticias-ecuador/las-diversidades-sociales-y-sexuales-aun-son-incomodas-601395.html#.UxEI5zuDlR8.facebook |date=April 13, 2014 }} ''Hoy'', 23 February 2014</ref> A regional QP colloquium was organised in Quito in October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Announcement of the Colloquium|url=http://www.flacso.org.ec/portal/eventos/i-coloquio-internacional-queer-interdisciplinariobrpensando-lo-queer-desde-y-en-america-latina.696|work=Faculdad Lationoamericana de Ciencias Sociales Sede Ecuador|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> QP 5 organisers continue to create social impact after the event, e.g. by lobbying for Equal Marriage in Ecuador.<ref>{{cite AV media | title = Campaña y lucha por el Matrimonio Civil Igualitario en Ecuador |trans-title=Campaign and the Struggle for Equal Civil Marriage in Ecuador | medium = Youtube | language = Spanish| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l796ixIRyn8 | accessdate = April 15, 2014}}</ref> The QP 5 book appeared early 2016.<ref name="QP5">Viteri, María Amelia / Lavinas Picq, Manuela (eds), [http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=86624&concordeid=431924 Queering Paradigms V]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}: Queering Narratives of Modernity, Peter Lang (2016)</ref>
==Queering Paradigms VI (July 2015)== Organised by QP founder B Scherer, QP 6 has taken place in the south of England in July 2015 and focused on the intersection of disability studies and queer studies. Held both at the [[University of Winchester]] and Canterbury Christ Church University, QP 6 part-merged with the VariAbilities II conference.<ref name="IntRel"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Ethics Beyond Troubling: Towards Queer(ed) (Vari)Ability|url=https://www.canterbury.ac.uk/arts-and-humanities/school-of-humanities/religion-philosophy-and-ethics/research/queering-paradigms-6.aspx}}</ref> In a final event an Emerging Scholars' day was held at the University of Kent organised by the Centre for Gender, Sexuality and Writing.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=KentCGSW|author=CGSW|number=624833343851507712|date=25 July 2015|title=Looking forward to welcoming all of @QueeringP6 and @VaribConf delegates to @UniKent today #EmergingScholars}}</ref>
==Queering Paradigms VII (June 2016)== [[File:QueeringParadigms7_KeynotersAndOrganisers.jpg|thumb|right|QP 7 organisers and keynoters]] QP 7 took place on the Cayman Islands and was organised by local LGBTIQ+ activists under the sponsorship of Canterbury Christ Church University, UK.<ref>{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms 7 CfP|url=http://queeringparadigms.com/2016/01/10/queering-paradigm-7-cfp/|work=QueeringParadigms.com|accessdate=January 17, 2016}}</ref>
Key speakers were the Rt. Rev. Dr. [[Alan Wilson (bishop)|Alan Wilson]], Bishop of Buckingham and Professor Emeritus [[Raúl Zaffaroni|Eugenio Raúl Zaffaroni]], justice of the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bishop to speak on religion and homosexuality|url=https://caymannewsservice.com/2016/04/bishop-to-speak-on-religion-and-homosexuality/|accessdate=April 10, 2016}}</ref>
Because the conference attracted some opposition from local politicians there was a police presence; there were however no reported disturbances.<ref>{{cite web|title=Upcoming LGBT Conference Draws Ire of Bodden Town MLA|url=https://caymannewsservice.com/2016/06/gay-marriage-here-to-stay-says-bishop/comment-page-1/|work=Cayman News Service|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gay marriage here to stay, says bishop|url=https://caymannewsservice.com/2016/06/gay-marriage-here-to-stay-says-bishop/comment-page-1/|work=Cayman News Service|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Queering Paradigms VIII (September 2017)== QP 8 was organised by a collective of activists and academics (M. Katharina Wiedlack, Masha Neufeld, Masha Godovannaya, Tania Zabolotnaya and others) in Vienna from 20 September until 23 September 2017 at the University of Vienna.<ref>{{cite web|title=Queering Paradigms VIII|url=http://qp8.univie.ac.at/|work=Universität Wien|accessdate=April 7, 2017}}</ref>
==Queering Paradigms IX (July 2018)== Organised by Nicole L Asquith ([[Western Sydney University]]), Matthew Ball (Queensland University of Technology), Trudie Broderick (Black Rainbow), Angela Dwyer ([[University of Tasmania]]),Justin Ellis ([[University of Sydney]]) QP9 took place in Sydney from 11 July to 13 July at the University of Sydney.<ref>{{cite web|title=Queer(y)ing Justice in the Global South Conference|url=http://sydney.edu.au/news/law/457.html?eventid=11768|work=University of Sydney|accessdate=July 21, 2018}}</ref>
Key Speakers were Dameyon Bonson (Black Rainbow, Australia), Professor Jo Phoenix (Open University, UK) and Dr Jace Valcore (University of Houston Downtown, USA)

'''Sacralism''' is the confluence of [[separation of church and state|church and state]] wherein one is called upon to change the other.
'''Christian sacralism''' is, according to Verduin,<ref>Verduin, Leonard ''The anatomy of a hybrid : a study in church-state relationships'', Grand Rapids, Mich. : Eerdmans, (1976) {{ISBN|0-8028-1615-0}}</ref> the [[multicultural|hybrid]] product that resulted from the colossal change known as the [[Constantinian shift]] that began early in the fourth century AD, when Christianity was granted official tolerance in the [[Roman Empire]] by the [[Emperor Constantine]], and was completed by the [[Emperor Theodosius]]'s declaration in 392 outlawing paganism and making Christianity the official religion of the Empire.
A [[Latin]] saying that has often been used to describe the principle of sacralism is '''''cuius regio, eius religio''''', or "who has region, decides religion." The idea was that the ruler of each individual area would decide the religion of those under his control based upon his own faith.
==See also== *[[Theocracy]] *[[Separation of church and state]] *The [[Anabaptists]] — whose history illustrates a continued rejection of sacralism.

{{Refimprove|date=November 2014}} '''Scotland Against Crooked Lawyers''' (SACL) is a [[pressure group]], it was also registered [[List of political parties in Scotland|political party]], dedicated to exposing alleged corruption within the [[Scottish legal profession]], Court System, and the Scottish Government. Their stated main aim is to end the system of self-regulation for [[solicitor]]s in [[Scotland]]. Currently conduct complaints against member solicitors are handled by the [[Law Society of Scotland]] with other complaints being dealt with by the [[Scottish Legal Complaints Commission]], with independent adjudication provided by the [[Scottish Legal Services Ombudsman]].
==Cause of complaint== Scotland Against Crooked Lawyers state that "Of all the professions that have evolved in our society, none have ever come close to matching the legal profession for downright deceit and dishonesty. The legal profession is immutable, intransigent, self-protective, unaccountable, incompetent and corrupt. For over 500 years this profession has been tyrannising, misleading and oppressing the Scottish people." [https://web.archive.org/web/20060108174647/http://www.unjustis.co.uk/Support/similar_sites.htm]
==Website== The group previously hosted a website where they featured a "rogues gallery", posting details of lawyers that the group alleged were corrupt.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12410267._apos_Rogues_gallery_apos__websites_to_expose_mystery_pursuer/ |title='Rogues gallery' websites to expose mystery pursuer |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |location=Glasgow |date=29 November 2004 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> In 2004 their US-based internet service provider had some pressure applied to them and switched the group's website off.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12757062.Lawful_lawyers_need_not_fear_website/ |title=Lawful lawyers need not fear website |work=The Herald |location=Glasgow |date=12 February 2007 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
==Politics== The group fielded two candidates at the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2007]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/6603083.stm |title=Smaller Scots parties 'no jokers' |first=John |last=Knox |work=[[BBC News]] |date=28 April 2007}}</ref> Having only attracted a small number of votes, the group lost their deposit for the two candidates it fielded, then failed in their attempt to bring a small claim against Edinburgh City Council for that amount.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1005364.aspx |title=SACL fails with election claim |work=The Journal |publisher=[[Law Society of Scotland]] |date=6 June 2008 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010]] the party registered a man, Robert Green , from Warrington as a candidate for [[Aberdeen South (UK Parliament constituency)|Aberdeen South]], despite him having bail conditions that prohibited him from entering the city. <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/general-election-2010-wannabe-mp-who-s-banned-from-scottish-seat-he-wants-to-represent-1-800704 |title=General Election 2010: Wannabe MP who's banned from Scottish seat he wants to represent |work=The Scotsman |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
They were among 462 parties registered at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/general-election-2015-a-guide-to-the-smaller-parties-from-the-the-national-health-action-party-to-10227365.html |title=General Election 2015: A guide to the smaller parties, from the National Health Action Party to the Church of the Militant Elvis Party |first=Simon |last=Usborne |work=[[The Independent]] |date=5 May 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
==Protests== Members of Scotland Against Crooked Lawyers hold regular protests outside the [[Scottish Parliament]] buildings at [[Holyrood, Edinburgh|Holyrood]], as well as other locations such as the [[Law Society of Scotland]] main office in Drumsheugh Gardens, and outside the [[Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service]] in Chambers Street, all in [[Edinburgh]].
==Leading members== SACL leading members include prominent legal campaigner Stuart Usher, of the Usher Distillery Family. The Usher family were well known for their generosity to Scottish charitable causes, including [[Usher Hall]] in [[Edinburgh]].

'''Single-peaked preferences''' are a kind of [[preference relation]]s. A group of agents is said to have single-peaked-preferences if: # Each agent has an ideal choice in the set; and # For each agent, outcomes that are further from his ideal choice are preferred less.
Single-peaked preferences are typical of one-dimensional domains. A typical example is when several consumers have to decide on the amount of [[public good]] to purchase. The amount is a one-dimensional variable. Usually, each consumer decides on a certain quantity which is best for him, and if the actual quantity is more/less than that ideal quantity, the agent is then less satisfied.
With single-peaked preferences, there is a simple [[truthful mechanism]] for selecting an outcome: it is to select the median quantity. See the [[median voter theorem]]. It is truthful because the median function satisfies the [[Monotonicity (mechanism design)|strong monotonicity]] property.
== Formal definition ==
Take an ordered set of outcomes: <math>\{x_1,\ldots,x_N\}</math>. An agent has a "single-peaked" preference relation over outcomes, <math>\succsim</math>, or "single-peaked preferences", if there exists a unique <math>x^*\in\{x_1,\ldots,x_N\}</math> such that
<math>x_m<x_n \leq x^* \Rightarrow x_n \succ x_m</math>
<math>x_m>x_n \geq x^* \Rightarrow x_n \succ x_m</math>
In words, <math>x^*</math> is the ideal point. When the agent compares between two outcomes that are both to the right or to the left of the ideal point, they strictly prefer whichever option is closest to <math>x^*</math>.
== Some examples ==
The following graphs show three preferences that are single-peaked over outcomes {A,B,C,D,E}. On the vertical axis, the number represents the preference ranking of the outcome, with 1 being most preferred. Two outcomes that are equally preferred have the same ranking.
[[File:Singlepeaked1.jpg|300px]]
The following graph gives two examples of preferences that are not single-peaked. The blue preferences are clearly not single-peaked because the preference ranking spikes down for "D" and then spikes up for "E". The green preferences are not single-peaked because they have two outcomes that are the most preferred: "B" and "C". Such preferences are sometimes called single-plateaued.
[[File:Singlepeaked2.jpg|300px]]
== Interpretations ==
Single-peaked preferences have a number of interpretations for different applications.
A simple application of ideological preferences is to think of the outcome space <math>\{x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n\}</math> as locations on a street and each <math>x_i</math> as the address of an individual. Suppose a single bus stop has to be located on the street and every individual wishes to walk as little as possible to the stop. Individuals then have single-peaked preferences: individual <math>i</math>'s ideal point is <math>x_i</math> and she dislikes other locations the farther they are to the west or the farther they are to the east.
The outcome space can also be thought as different policies in an ideological spectrum: policies from the Left vs policies from the Right; policies that are more liberal vs policies that are more conservative; policies that are pro free markets vs policies that are pro state intervention. Voters have single-peaked preferences if they have an ideal balance between the two directions of the ideological spectrum and if they dislike policies the farther away they are from their ideal point.
