The '''Sunlight Foundation''' is an American [[501(c)(3)]] nonpartisan, [[nonprofit organization]] that advocates for [[open government]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marohn|first1=Kirsti|title=Website offers peek at politicians' deleted tweets|url=http://www.sctimes.com/story/watchdog/2015/04/09/website-offers-peek-at-politicians-deleted-tweets/25521423/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=St. Cloud Times|date=April 9, 2015}}</ref> The organization was founded in April 2006 with the goal of increasing [[Transparency (social)|transparency]] and [[accountability]] in the [[United States Congress]], the [[Federal government of the United States|executive branch]], and in state and local governments.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lichterman|first1=Joseph|title=Q&A: Ellen Miller on the Sunlight Foundation’s role in increasing the availability of open data|url=http://www.niemanlab.org/2014/03/qa-ellen-miller-on-the-sunlight-foundations-role-in-increasing-the-availability-of-open-data/|accessdate=21 April 2015|publisher=Nieman Journalism Lab|date=March 6, 2014}}</ref> The foundation's primary focus is the role of money in politics. The organization seeks to increase campaign finance regulations and disclosure requirements.<ref name="shedlight" />
==Organizational overview== ===Founding=== The Sunlight Foundation was founded by [[Ellen S. Miller]] and Michael R. Klein because of their concern about the influence of money in politics. The Foundation was launched in April 2006 with a $3.5 million contribution from co-founder Klein, a securities lawyer who started the firm CoStar Group Inc. in the 1980s.<ref name="shedlight">{{cite news |title=Aiming to Shed Light on Lawmakers |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/25/AR2006042501699.html |first=Jeffrey |last=Birnbaum |date=April 26, 2006 |accessdate=2008-03-22 |work=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref><ref name="ethicsreform">{{cite news |url=http://www.sunlightfoundation.com/node/488 |title=New Group Sees Public Craving Ethics Reform |work=[[Roll Call]] |date=April 27, 2006 |first=Elysha |last=Tenenbaum |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070303074549/http://www.sunlightfoundation.com/node/488 |archivedate=March 3, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="miller">{{cite news |url=http://www.sunlightfoundation.com/press/ellen_cspan |title=Ellen Miller on C-Span's ''Washington Journal'' |publisher=[[C-SPAN]] |date=May 22, 2006 |accessdate=2008-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928011545/http://www.sunlightfoundation.com/press/ellen_cspan |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
At its founding, Sunlight's board was constituted of Klein, serving as chairman, Miller serving as secretary and treasurer, and Nicholas J. Klein, Klein's son. <ref>{{cite news |last1=Sunlight |first1=Board |title=Sunlight Original Board |url=http://www.sunlightfoundation.com:80/node/160 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070118153220/http://www.sunlightfoundation.com:80/node/160 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-01-18 |accessdate=June 7, 2018 |work=[[Wayback Machine snapshot of SunlightFoundation.com]] |date=October 2007}}</ref>
Sunlight's original advisory board was constituted of [[Esther Dyson]], [[Craig Newmark]] and [[Kim Malone]]. [[Jimmy Wales]], [[Yochai Benkler]], [[Charles Lewis (journalist)|Charles Lewis]], [[Lawrence Lessig]], Kim Scott, and [[Mitch Kapor]] later joined as advisors, with Newmark and Dyson moving to the board.
===Personnel===
Miller was the Sunlight Foundation's executive director from 2006 until her retirement in 2014. The first national director of the organization was law professor [[Zephyr Teachout]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mogulescu |first1=Miles |title=Run, Zephyr, Run — Teachout Should Challenge Hillary for the Democratic Presidential Nomination |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/miles-mogulescu/run-zephyr-runteachout-sh_b_5805234.html |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=September 11, 2014 }}</ref>
In September 2014, [[Christopher T. Gates]] was selected as the organization's new president, after the board conducted a search.<ref name="gates">{{cite news |last1=Lippman |first1=Daniel |title=Sunlight Foundation picks new chief |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/09/chris-gates-sunlight-foundation-110697.html |accessdate=April 21, 2015 |publisher=Politico |date=September 8, 2014 }}</ref> Gates was formerly the chairman of the [[Colorado Democratic Party]] and executive director of Philanthropy for Active Civic Engagement and the [[National Civic League]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Greene |first1=Susan |title=Chris Gates to head national watchdog group |url=http://www.coloradoindependent.com/149187/chris-gates-to-head-national-watchdog-group |accessdate=April 21, 2015 |work=Colorado Independent |date=September 9, 2014}}</ref>
In 2010, Matt Halprin of the [[Omidyar Network]] joined the board. In 2011, lawyer Andrew McLaughlin joined the board. In 2013, Stacey Donahue of the Omidyar Network joined, replacing Halprin. In 2014, Sunlight announced that [[Sue Gardner]], Allison Fine, Mark Horvit and Daniel X. O’Neil would join its board of directors. <ref>{{cite news |last1=Sunlight |first1=Board |title=New Sunlight Board Members |url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/2014/12/23/sunlight-welcomes-new-board-members/ |accessdate=June 7, 2018 |work=[[SunlightFoundation.com]] |date=December 11, 2014 }}</ref>. Donahue subsequently left.
In January 2015, the Sunlight Foundation restructured, combining its reporting staff with its communications team. As a result of the restructuring, three staffers left the organization, including managing editor Kathy Kiely, who was laid off.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mullin |first1=Benjamin |title=3 leave in restructuring of Sunlight Foundation |url=http://www.poynter.org/news/mediawire/316607/3-leave-in-restructuring-of-sunlight-foundation/ |accessdate=6 November 2015 |publisher=[[Poynter Institute]] |date=February 2, 2015 }}</ref> In June 2015, four more staffers left the organization.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mullin |first1=Benjamin |title=4 staffers to exit The Sunlight Foundation |url=http://www.poynter.org/news/mediawire/352297/4-staffers-to-exit-the-sunlight-foundation/ |accessdate=6 November 2015 |publisher=Poynter Institute |date=June 19, 2015 }}</ref> Niko Klein and Gardner left the board.
In January 2016, Klein announced on Sunlight's blog that the organization was looking for a new chief executive, with Gates leaving the organization and John Wonderlich serving as the interim executive director.<ref name="new CEO 2016">{{cite web |url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/blog/2016/01/04/a-message-from-michael-klein-co-founder-and-chairman-of-the-sunlight-foundation/ |title=A message from Michael Klein, co-founder and chairman of the Sunlight Foundation |last1=Klein |first1=Michael |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |date=January 4, 2016 |accessdate=January 12, 2016 }}</ref>
In September 2016, Klein announced on Sunlight's blog that Sunlight Labs would be shutting down and the board was exploring potential mergers.<ref name="Labs shut down">{{cite web |url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/2016/09/20/statement-from-sunlight-foundations-board-chairman/ |title=A message from Michael Klein, co-founder and chairman of the Sunlight Foundation |last1=Klein |first1=Michael |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |date=September 20, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2017 }}</ref>O'Neil subsequently left the board.
Klein announced on Sunlight's blog on December 16 that the organization would remain independent, with Wonderlich becoming the permanent executive director and Alexander B. Howard promoted to be the deputy director.<ref name="new leadership">{{cite web |url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/2016/12/16/sunlight-will-endure/ |title=A message from Michael Klein, co-founder and chairman of the Sunlight Foundation |last1=Klein |first1=Michael |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |date=January 4, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2017 }}</ref>. Fine, Horvit, McLaughlin, and Dyson all left the board.<ref name="new leadership 2">{{cite web |url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/about/board/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110193001/https://sunlightfoundation.com/about/board/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2017-01-10 |title=Sunlight Board of Directors in January 2017 |last1=2017 |first1=Board |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |date=January 2017 |accessdate=June 7, 2018 }}</ref>
In March 2018, [[Katherine Maher]] and Zoe Reiter joined Klein, Newmark and Wonderlich on the board.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sunlight Foundation Board |url=http://sunlightfoundation.com/about/board/ |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |accessdate=July 5, 2018 }}</ref>
In May 2018, the Huffington Post reported that [[Clay Johnson (technologist)|Clay Johnson]], former director of Sunlight Labs, had been accused of sexual misconduct and mistreatment by multiple women during his employment at Sunlight and left after a staff insurrection. <ref>{{cite web |title=Johnson sexual harassment |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/clay-johnson-attempted-rape-dean-campaign_us_5aebb6d7e4b0c4f1932090ac |publisher=Huffington Post |accessdate=July 5, 2018 }}</ref>. Subsequently, Sunlight's board announced that it would conduct a review of the organization's history. <ref>{{cite web |title=Board review |url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/2018/05/21/our-process-for-reviewing-sunlights-history/ |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |accessdate=July 5, 2018 }}</ref>
===Awards===
In July 2009, the Sunlight Foundation received the Public Access to Government Information Award from the [[American Association of Law Libraries]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aallnet.org/about/award_information.asp |title=Public Access to Government Information Award |publisher=[[American Association of Law Libraries]] |accessdate=January 11, 2011 }}</ref>
In July 2010, the Sunlight Foundation won the grand prize of the [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation|Knight]]-Batten Awards for Innovations in Journalism for their Sunlight Live project that incorporates streaming video, liveblogging, social networking, and data presentation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cohen |first1=David|title=2010 Knight-Batten Awards for Innovation in Journalism: Sunlight Foundation Wins Grand Prize |url=http://www.adweek.com/socialtimes/2010-knight-batten-awards-for-innovation-in-journalism-sunlight-foundation-wins-grand-prize/53919 |accessdate=April 21, 2015 |work=Social Times |date=July 19, 2010 }}</ref>
===Funding===
The Sunlight Foundation's donors include the [[Open Society Foundations]], [[The Pew Charitable Trusts]], the [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation]], the [[Rockefeller Foundation]], the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Hewlett Foundation|William and Flora Hewlett Foundation]], the [[Omidyar Network]], [[Bloomberg Philanthropies]], and the [[Laura and John Arnold Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web |title=How We're Funded |url=http://sunlightfoundation.com/about/funding/ |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |accessdate=November 6, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=A Brief History of the Sunlight Foundation |url=http://sunlightfoundation.com/about/history/ |publisher=Sunlight Foundation |accessdate=April 21, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Tapscott |first1=Mark |title=Sunlight Foundation poses 23 key questions Clinton must answer on her emails |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/sunlight-foundation-poses-23-key-questions-clinton-must-answer-on-her-emails/article/2561106 |accessdate=April 21, 2015 |work=[[The Washington Examiner]] |date=March 5, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The Omidyar way of giving |url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21588353-founder-ebay-aims-be-more-entrepreneurial-philanthropist-his-predecessors |accessdate=21 April 2015|work=[[The Economist]] |date=October 26, 2013 }}</ref>
==Policy positions== The Sunlight Foundation advocates for more regulation and limitations regarding [[campaign finance]]. The organization opposed the ruling in ''[[Citizens United v. FEC]]'', calling it "disastrous."<ref name=positions>{{cite news|last1=Wonderlich|first1=John|title=Disclosing Money in Elections|url=http://sunlightfoundation.com/policy/disclosingmoney/|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Sunlight Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Issues|url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/issues/|publisher=Sunlight Foundation|accessdate=6 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118073041/http://sunlightfoundation.com/issues/|archivedate=18 November 2015|df=}}</ref> The organization supported the [[DISCLOSE Act]], a congressional bill that would have enacted stricter campaign finance regulations by requiring increased disclosure of political spending in federal elections.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Moyers|first1=Bill|title=Citizens Mobilizing Against Citizens United|url=http://billmoyers.com/content/citizens-mobilizing-against-citizens-united/|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Moyers & Company|date=March 9, 2012}}</ref> The Sunlight Foundation believes that Congress should mandate real-time online disclosure of political contributions.<ref name=positions/> It opposes [[dark money]], a term used to describe funds given to nonprofit organizations that are not required to disclose their donors.<ref name=gates/>
==Activities== [[File:FEC Colbert Super PAC.jpg|thumb|250px|Demonstrators from the Sunlight Foundation outside [[Federal Election Commission]] offices as they discuss the application of [[Colbert Super PAC]]]] The Sunlight Foundation's initiatives have included Sunlight Labs, which is an open source community that collects and organizes public data;<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gilbertson|first1=Scott|title=Sunlight Labs Offering $5K for Best Government Data Mashups|url=https://www.wired.com/2010/03/sunlight-labs-offering-5k-for-best-government-data-mashups/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Wired|date=March 29, 2010}}</ref> Influence Explorer, which is an online tool for tracking money in politics;<ref>{{cite news|last1=Racino|first1=Brad|title=How To Uncover A Scandal From Your Couch|url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2014/jan/27/how-uncover-scandal-you-couch/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=KPBS|date=January 27, 2014}}</ref> and Foreign Influence Explorer, which tracks lobbyists who represent foreign clients in Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Itkowitz|first1=Colby|title=Which foreign countries spent the most to influence U.S. politics?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/in-the-loop/wp/2014/05/14/which-foreign-countries-spent-the-most-to-influence-u-s-politics/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=May 14, 2014}}</ref>
In 2006, the Sunlight Foundation provided funding to the [[Center for Responsive Politics]] to improve its campaign finance and lobbying listings and to the [[Center for Media and Democracy]] to oversee a joint project called Congresspedia.<ref name="shedlight"/> In June 2006, the Sunlight Foundation reported on Republican [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|House Speaker]] [[Dennis Hastert]]'s real estate investments, accusing Hastert of not divulging connections between a $207 million earmark he won for a highway and an investment he and his wife made in nearby land.<ref name="hastertcbs">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/06/22/politics/main1740900.shtml |title=Speaker Hastert's Land Deal Questioned |date=2006-06-22 |accessdate=2008-03-22 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[CBS News]]}}</ref>
==={{anchor|OpenCongressAnchor}}Open House Project and OpenCongress.org===
In January 2007, the Sunlight Foundation launched the Open House Project, a working group designed to make congressional procedures more transparent.<ref name=pbs>{{cite news|last1=Glaser|first1=Mark|title=Sunlight Foundation Mixes Tech, Citizen Journalism to Open Congress|url=https://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2007/04/sunlight-foundation-mixes-tech-citizen-journalism-to-open-congress094/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=PBS|date=April 4, 2007}}</ref> In February 2007, the [[Participatory Politics Foundation]] and the Sunlight Foundation launched OpenCongress.org, a site to track the full text of legislation and build a community to better follow congressional activities.<ref name=pbs/> Originally run by the Participatory Politics Foundation with funding from the Sunlight Foundation, in 2013 the Sunlight Foundation overtook operations of OpenCongress.org.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Margolies|first1=Nicko|title=Reintroducing OpenCongress: Now From The Sunlight Foundation|url=http://sunlightfoundation.com/blog/2013/10/29/reintroducing-opencongress-now-from-the-sunlight-foundation/|publisher=Sunlight Foundation|accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref>. In 2016, Sunlight retired OpenCongress and directed its community to GovTrack.us.<ref name=Govtrack>{{cite web|last1=Duffy|first1=Kat|title=Sunlight Foundation Mixes Tech, Citizen Journalism to Open Congress|url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/2016/02/12/farewell-opencongress-hello-govtrack/4/|accessdate=20 January 2017|date=February 12, 2016}}</ref> h
===EarmarkWatch.org=== In October 2007, the Sunlight Foundation joined [[Taxpayers for Common Sense]] to launch EarmarkWatch.org, a project that asked citizens to research over 3,000 [[Earmark (politics)|earmarks]] and identify the sponsors and recipients.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://philanthropy.com/article/Seeking-Online-Exposure/61177/|title=Seeking Online Exposure|publisher=[[The Chronicle of Philanthropy]]|author=Suzanne Perry|date=2008-01-10|accessdate=2010-08-18}}</ref> In 2008, the Sunlight Foundation launched a project called Public Markup. The project [[crowdsourced]] ideas for model transparency legislation.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lai Striland|first1=Sarah|title=Sunlight Foundation Asks The Public For Ideas On A More Accountable Government|url=https://www.wired.com/2008/03/sunlight-founda/|accessdate=17 April 2015|publisher=Wired|date=March 31, 2008}}</ref>
===Scout===
Scout was a tool to create customized keyword alerts that notify users whenever the subscribed issue or bill is talked about in Congress, mentioned in the Federal Register or comes up in state legislation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Researching Current Federal Legislation and Regulations: A Guide to Resources for Congressional Staff |url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL33895.pdf |publisher=Congressional Research Service |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> During beta testing Scout helped a coalition of transparency advocates oppose and remove a [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] exemption for a bill.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sunlight’s Scout is a promising new tool |url=http://www.cjr.org/the_kicker/sunlights_scout_is_a_promising.php |publisher=Columbia Journalism Review |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>
===Call on Congress===
Call on Congress was a [[Toll-free telephone number|toll free phone number]] individuals can call to learn about what Congress is doing.<ref>{{cite web |title=Call on Congress: A New/Free Telephone Service to Access Info About the U.S. Congress |url=http://www.infodocket.com/2012/06/12/call-on-congress-a-newfree-telephone-service-to-access-info-about-the-u-s-congress/ |publisher=InfoDocket |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> The project hopes to bridge the [[digital divide]] by letting callers find out how their representatives are voting on bills and raising campaign money or connect directly to the lawmakers’ Capitol Hill offices and get details on where to vote on Election Day.<ref>{{cite web |title=Low-Tech Phone Service Connects Citizens to Congressional Info |url=http://www.govtech.com/e-government/Low-Tech-Phone-Service-Connects-Citizens-Congressional.html |publisher=Government Technology |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>
===Politwoops=== Politiwoops was a Sunlight Foundation project which published an archive of thousands of deleted [[Twitter|tweets]] by U.S. politicians. The project prompted [[Jeff Miller (Florida politician)|Rep. Jeff Miller]] to delete his Twitter account after his tweet questioning [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]]'s citizenship was made public.<ref>{{cite web |title=What Tweets Do Politicians Delete? 'Politwoops' Can Tell You |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2012/05/31/154058713/what-tweets-do-politicians-delete-politwoops-can-tell-you |publisher=NPR |accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Congressman’s Deleted Twitter Poll: "Was Obama Born in the United States?" |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/weigel/2012/05/30/congressman_jeff_miller_s_office_sends_birther_twitter_poll_deletes_it_.html |publisher=Slate |accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> Other incidents covered by Politwoops include a number of Republican politicians reacting to incorrect news of the ruling in the [[National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius|Supreme Court's case about health care reform]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Erroneous #Scotus Tweets Saved Forever |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2012/06/28/erroneous-scotus-tweets-saved-forever/ |publisher=The Wall Street Journal's Washington Wire |accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> violations of the social media policies of the House of Representatives' Congressional Handbook by tweeting campaign information<ref>{{cite web |title=Twoops! Romney-Ryan ticket has some lawmakers violating congressional Twitter rules |url=http://reporting.sunlightfoundation.com/2012/deleted-tweets-supporting-rep-ryan-romneys-running-mate/ |publisher=Sunlight Foundation Reporting Group |accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> and six politicians who deleted tweets praising and welcoming home [[Bowe Bergdahl#Release|Taliban prisoner Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl]] after questions arose over the prisoner swap that freed him.<ref>{{cite web |title=Politicians Delete Digital Praise of Bowe Bergdahl Release |url=http://mashable.com/2014/06/03/republicans-delete-bowe-bergdahl-praise/ |publisher=Mashable |accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' selected Politwoops as one of their 50 Best Websites of 2012, calling it "strangely fascinating."<ref>{{cite news |title=50 Best Websites 2012 |url=http://techland.time.com/2012/09/18/50-best-websites-2012/slide/politiwoops/#politiwoops |publisher=TIME Magazine |accessdate=2012-09-20 |date=2012-09-18}}</ref>
Politiwoops went on hiatus in May 2015 when Twitter, citing concerns over user privacy, revoked the Sunlight Foundation's permission to use its [[Application programming interface|application program interface]];<ref>{{cite news|last1=Trujillo|first1=Mario|title=Sunlight Foundation rips Twitter for pulling plug on lawmaker archive|url=http://thehill.com/policy/technology/244049-sunlight-foundation-twitter-decision-at-odds-with-understanding-of|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=The Hill|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> however, in November 2015, Twitter CEO [[Jack Dorsey]] conceded that this had been a mistake,<ref name=VergeDorsey>[https://www.theverge.com/2015/10/21/9586084/jack-dorsey-twitter-ceo-apology-developers Jack Dorsey apologizes to Twitter developers for chasing them away], by Nick Statt, at ''[[the Verge]]''; published October 21, 2015; retrieved October 21, 2016</ref> and Politwoops resumed international activity in January 2016 and American activity in February 2016.<ref name=VergeReturn>[https://www.theverge.com/2016/2/9/10952050/politwoops-returns-twitter-politicians-deleted-tweets Politwoops returns to the US to archive politicians' deleted tweets], by Nick Statt, at ''[[the Verge]]''; published February 9, 2016; retrieved October 21, 2016</ref>. [[ProPublica]] now operates the U.S. version of the website.
===Upwardly Mobile===
In April 2012, the Sunlight Foundation released Upwardly Mobile, a web application to research where in the United States individuals could enjoy financial security and an improved quality of life. The relocation search tool is mostly powered by publicly available federal economic data that includes employment, salaries, average rents, and local medical and transportation costs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Would You Be Better Off in a Different City? |url=http://www.theatlanticcities.com/technology/2012/04/would-you-be-better-different-city/1678 |publisher=The Atlantic |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Is it time for you to move? |url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/collections/special/columns/news_cut/archive/2012/04/is_it_time_for_you_to_move.shtml |publisher=Minnesota Public Radio |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>
===Churnalism===
The online Churnalism tool was launched in 2013 in collaboration with the [[Media Standards Trust]] as an open-source plagiarism detection engine. The tool allows users to compare two sources of text to analyze similarities.<ref name="Rosen">{{cite web|title=Is It Journalism, or Just a Repackaged Press Release? Here's a Tool to Help You Find Out|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/04/is-it-journalism-or-just-a-repackaged-press-release/275206/|work=The Atlantic|publisher=The Atlantic Monthly Group|accessdate=24 April 2013|author=Rebecca J. Rosen|date=23 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Moore|first1=Martin|title=How to Detect Original Journalism vs. Churnalism from Press Releases|url=https://www.pbs.org/idealab/2013/04/how-to-detect-original-journalism-vs-churnalism-from-press-releases114/|accessdate=21 April 2015|publisher=PBS|date=April 26, 2013}}</ref>
===Ad Hawk===
In 2012, the Sunlight Foundation launched a mobile application called "Ad Hawk" to identify [[Campaign advertising|political ads]]. Similar to many song identification services, Ad Hawk makes an [[acoustic fingerprint]] based on audio recorded while a television or radio ad plays and compares it against a central database for a match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/tools/ad-hawk/|title=Ad Hawk|publisher=Sunlight Foundation|access-date=31 July 2016}}</ref> Ad Hawk will return information from a variety of sources about the candidate, organization and issues ads if a match is found.<ref>{{cite web |title=The New Essential Apps August 2012 |url=https://gizmodo.com/5939615/the-new-essential-apps-august-2012 |publisher=Gizmodo |accessdate=2012-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fact Attack: A New App Watches Political Ads Like a Hawk |url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/news-and-opinion/cover-story/Ad-Buster-168552256.html |publisher=Philadelphia Weekly |accessdate=2012-09-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130201085633/http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/news-and-opinion/cover-story/Ad-Buster-168552256.html |archivedate=2013-02-01 |df= }}</ref>
===Events and contests===
In 2009, the Sunlight Foundation held the first annual TransparencyCamp, a conference where open government advocates met to discuss problems and solutions with government data.<ref name="WaPo Tcamp">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/03/AR2010040304957_pf.html|title=A hotbed of techie agents of government transparency|date=2010-04-04|accessdate=2010-08-18|publisher=Washington Post | first=Mike | last=Musgrove}}</ref>
In March 2010, the Sunlight Foundation announced the Design for America contest to encourage visualizations to make complex government information more understandable to citizens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.good.is/post/design-for-america-help-make-government-data-easier-to-understand/|title=Design for America: Help Make Government Data Easier to Understand|publisher=GOOD Magazine Blog|author=Andrew Price|date=2010-05-03|accessdate=2010-08-18}}</ref>
In August 2012, the Sunlight Foundation launched Sunlight Academy, an interactive training portal to help [[journalist]]s, [[Congressional staff|staffers]], and [[Citizenship in the United States|citizens]] use transparency tools to research issues more effectively.<ref>{{cite web |title=Low-Tech Phone Service Connects Citizens to Congressional Info |url=http://www.mediabistro.com/10000words/watchdog-journalism-skills-sunlight-foundation_b15133 |publisher=[[Mediabistro.com|Mediabistro]]'s 10,000 Words |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>

{{For|the town in [[Botswana]]|Seleka, Botswana}} {{infobox war faction |name= Séléka CPSK-CPJP-UFDR |native_name |native_name_lang |war= [[Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present)|Central African Republic Civil War]] |image= |caption= |active= September 2012–present |ideology= |leaders= [[Michel Djotodia]]
[[Joseph Zoundeiko]] (military wing) |clans= *[[Democratic Front of the Central African People]] (FDPC) *[[Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace]] (CPJP) *[[Union of Democratic Forces for Unity]] (UFDR) *[[Alliance for Revival and Rebuilding]] (A2R) *[[Patriotic Convention for Saving the Country]] (CPSK) |headquarters= |area= |strength= |partof= |previous= |next= |allies= |opponents= *[[Central African Armed Forces]] (Formerly, September 2012-March 2013) *[[Anti-balaka]] |battles= |url= }} '''Séléka CPSK-CPJP-UFDR''' is an alliance of rebel [[militia]] groups{{sfn|RFI|2012-12-20}} that subjugated the [[Central African Republic]] (CAR) on March 24, 2013.{{sfn|RFI|2013-12-31}}{{sfn|Pflanz|2013}}{{sfn|Châtelot|2013}} After its official dissolution in September 2013, the remaining rebel groups became known as '''Ex-Seleka'''. Séléka leader [[Michel Djotodia]] became the nation's president from March 2013 until his resignation in January 2014.{{sfn|RFI|2013-03-24}}{{sfn|Reuters|2013-03-24}} Members of Séléka are almost entirely Muslim.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/22/central-african-republic-verge-of-genocide The Guardian: "Unspeakable horrors in a country on the verge of genocide - Militias in the Central African Republic are slitting children's throats, razing villages and throwing young men to the crocodiles. What needs to happen before the world intervenes?" by David Smith] November 22, 2013[https://www.economist.com/blogs/baobab/2013/11/CAR The Economist: "The Central African Republic - Ever darker"] November 8, 2013[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24802898 BBC: "Central African Republic: Religious tinderbox"] November 4, 2013[http://www.theafricareport.com/Central-Africa/car-muslim-christian-tension-on-the-rise-since-coup.html Africa Report: "CAR: Muslim-Christian tension on the rise, since coup" By Konye Obaji Ori] November 6, 2013 ==Name== The word ''Seleka'' means "Coalition" in [[Sango language|Sango]], one of the CAR's two national languages, the other being French.{{sfn|AFP|2013-01-01}}{{sfn|Bouquiaux|1978|p= 307|ps= no entry exists for seleka between "sèlègbhia" (embassy) and "sèlèngbè (suffix)}} The international media has shortened the full name Séléka CPSK-CPJP-UFDR to ''la Séléka'' in French or often ''Seleka'' in English. The term ''Séléka'' had been used previously in CAR politics when [[Jean-Jacques Démafouth]] launched the political party [[New Alliance for Progress]] ({{lang-fr|Nouvelle Alliance pour le Progrès}}) with the Sango name ''Fini Seleka''.{{sfn|Démafouth|2006}} ==Background== The rebel coalition originated in an agreement signed between factions of the [[Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace]] (CPJP) and the [[Patriotic Convention for Saving the Country]] (CPSK), two of the CAR's many anti-government militias on August 20, 2012.{{sfn|Ibrahim|Abdraman|2012}} CPJP in this case refers to the "Fundamental" splinter group of the CPJP, one of many militias involved in the CAR's long-running [[Central African Republic Bush War|civil war]]. A different faction of the CPJP signed a peace accord with the government on August 25, 2012. The Seleka first emerged on September 15, 2012 under the name ''alliance CPSK-CPJP,'' when it published a press release taking responsibility for the [[Central African Republic conflict (2012–present)#Early skirmishes|attacks on three towns]] that day.{{sfn|Alkassim|2012}} It was the last of the major rebel groups to do so.{{sfn|RFI|2012}} The CPSK was hardly known.{{sfn|RFI|2012}} On December 15, 2012 the group published its first press release using the full name "Séléka CPSK-CPJP-UFDR" thus including the [[Union of Democratic Forces for Unity]] (UFDR). Two groups that did not appear in the title, the long-standing militia [[Democratic Front of the Central African People]] (FDPC), and the newly minted [[Alliance for Revival and Rebuilding]] (A2R), were also reportedly part of the alliance.{{sfn|RFI|2013-03-24}} The Seleka weren't an overtly religious movement, but they were mostly Muslim, as was Michel Djotodia, the president they installed in March 2013 after taking power. ==Civil War== The fighters that ushered in Djotodia ran wild across the country during his time in office, plundering villages and killing Christians as well as supporters of the former president Francois Bozize.[http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/africa/140426/banguis-last-muslims-stray-outside-the-safe-haven-court-death For Bangui's last Muslims, to stray outside the safe haven is to court death]. Retrieved 2014-04-26. In September 2013 Michel Djotodia announced that Seleka had been dissolved.[http://www.france24.com/en/20130913-central-african-republic-djotodia-dissolves-seleka-rebel-group CAR’s Djotodia dissolves Seleka rebel group] The disbanded group has dispersed into the countryside and have been committing mass atrocities according to [[Human Rights Watch]].[https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/11/24/central-african-republic-war-crimes-ex-seleka-rebels Human Rights Watch: "Central African Republic: War Crimes by Ex-Seleka Rebels - Hold Commander Accountable for Attack on Town"] November 25, 2013[http://www.citypress.co.za/news/killing-fields-car/ Zambia City Press: "The killing fields of CAR" by Nazanine Moshir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101172346/http://www.citypress.co.za/news/killing-fields-car/ |date=2014-11-01 }} November 10, 2013[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-international/car-tense-as-rebels-wreak-havoc/article5396065.ece The Hindu: "CAR tense as rebels wreak havoc" by David Smith] November 27, 2013[http://www.lanouvellecentrafrique.org/the-central-african-republic-ever-darker/ La Nouvelle Centra Afrique: "The Central African Republic: Ever darker"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131128174520/http://www.lanouvellecentrafrique.org/the-central-african-republic-ever-darker/ |date=2013-11-28 }} November 18, 2013[http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2013/11/17/we-live-and-die-animals-central-african-republic SBS: "We live and die like animals: The Central African Republic" By Peter Bouckaert] November 17, 2013 Executions, rape and looting by ex-Seleka fighters after the coup and disbanding have fomented religious tension where the population is 80% Christian.[http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/hundreds-of-vigilantes-attack-town-in-central-african-republic#sthash.j08OaZSa.dpuf Malay Online: "Hundreds of vigilantes attack town in Central African Republic] October 26, 2013 Christian militias, using the name [[anti-balaka]], have been formed to fight the Muslim Seleka. The United Nations is considering sending troops to stop the atrocities.[http://www.christiantoday.com/article/un.considers.sending.force.to.central.african.republic/34828.htm Christian Today: "UN considers sending force to Central African Republic"] November 26, 2013 On November 26, France indicated that it would boost its presence an additional 1,000 soldiers in the Central African Republic to augment its existent 400 troops if it receives U.N. backing.[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-france-centralafrican-20131126,0,7832212.story Chicago Tribune: "France to boost Central African force with U.N. backing" by Leigh Thomas and Joe Penney] November 26, 2013 ==Ex-Séléka militias== By 2015, there was virtually no government control outside of the capital, Bangui. Armed entrepreneurs have carved out personal fiefdoms in which they set up checkpoints, collect illegal taxes, and take in millions of dollars from the illicit [[coffee]], [[mineral]], and [[timber]] trades.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/10/28/one-day-we-will-start-a-big-war-central-african-republic-un-violence/|title=One day we will start a big war|publisher=Foreign Policy|accessdate=13 February 2017}} Months after the official dissolution of Seleka it was not known who in charge of Ex-Seleka factions during talks with Antibalaka until on 12 July 2014, Michel Djotodia was reinstated as the head of a faction of Séléka,Crispin Dembassa-Kette, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/12/us-centralafrica-rebels-idUSKBN0FH0NL20140712 "Central Africa Republic's ousted leader back in charge of Seleka"], Reuters, 12 July 2014. Retrieved 14 July 2014. which renamed itself '''The Popular Front for the Rebirth of Central African Republic''' (FPRC), also translated as "The Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central African Republic".[http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/07/13/central-african-republic-ex-president-re-elected-head-rebel-movement/ Central African Republic: Ex-president re-elected head of rebel movement] Associated Press. 13 July 2014. Retrieved 14 July 2014 Later in 2014, [[Noureddine Adam]] led the FPRC and began demanding independence for the predominantly Muslim north, a move rejected by another general, [[Ali Darassa]]. He formed another Ex-Seleka faction called the '''Union for Peace in the Central African Republic''' (UPC) which is dominant in and around Bambari while the FPRC's capital is in [[Bria, Central African Republic|Bria]]. Noureddine Adam declared the autonomous Republic of Logone on 14 December 2015; a spokesman for the [[Central African Republic]]'s transitional government denounced the rebel's declaration. Another group is the '''Central African Patriotic Movement''' (MPC) founded by Mahamat Al Khatim. Much of the violence in this phase of the conflict is between Ex-Seleka militias and is often ethnic in nature with the FPRC targeting [[Fulani people]] who largely make up the UPC and the UPC targeting the [[Kara people|Gula]] and [[Aiki language|Runga]] people, who largely make up FPRC, as being sympathetic to FPRC.{{cite web|url=https://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2017/02/24/central-african-republic-what's-gone-wrong|title=Central African Republic: What's gone wrong?|publisher=IRIN|date=24 February 2017|accessdate=26 February 2017}} Starting in November 2016, FPRC and MPC allied with their former enemy, the Anti-balaka, and attacked UPC.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/02/16/central-african-republic-executions-rebel-group|title=Central African Republic: Executions by rebel group|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=17 February 2017}} Most of the fighting is in the centrally located [[Ouaka]] prefecture, which has the country's second largest city [[Bambari]], because of its strategic location between the Muslim and Christian regions of the country and its wealth.{{cite web|url=https://international.la-croix.com/news/the-battle-of-ouaka-in-central-african-republic/4756|title=The battle of Ouaka in Central African Republic|publisher=LaCroix International|date=27 February 2017|accessdate=27 February 2017}} The fighting displaced 20,000 with the FPRC singling out Fulani people.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-centralafrica-violence-idUSKBN15R0WC|title=U.N. air strikes in Central African Republic kill several: militia|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=14 February 2017}} In February 2017, [[Joseph Zoundeiko]], the chief of staff of FPRC{{cite news |last= |first= |date=29 July 2014 |title=CAR crisis: Meeting the rebel army chief |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-28526362 |newspaper=BBC News |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }} who previously led the military wing of Seleka, was killed by MINUSCA after crossing one of the red lines.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/central-african-republic-war-fprc-car-556068|title=U.N. 'KILLS REBEL COMMANDER' IN CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC AIRSTRIKES|publisher=|accessdate=14 February 2017}} ==Atrocities== On September 18, 2013, the Seleka killed scores of unarmed civilians, according to Human Rights Watch.{{when|date=August 2017}} The Seleka has also engaged in wanton destruction of numerous homes and villages. The 79-page report, The Forgotten Human Rights Crisis in the Central African Republic," details the deliberate killing of civilians – including women, children, and the elderly – between March and June 2013 and confirms the deliberate destruction of more than 1,000 homes, both in the capital, Bangui, and in the provinces. Many villagers have fled their homes and are living in the bush in fear of new attacks. Human Rights Watch documented the deaths of scores of people from injuries, hunger or sickness. "Seleka leaders promised a new beginning for the people of the Central African Republic, but instead have carried out large-scale attacks on civilians, looting, and murder," said Daniel Bekele, Africa director at Human Rights Watch. "What's worse is that the Seleka have recruited children as young as 13 to carry out some of this carnage." On May 28, 2014, the Seleka members threw grenades before shooting indiscriminately at the [[Church of Fatima, Bangui|Church of Fatima]] in the capital Bangui, killing at least 11 people.[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27614401 CAR Seleka rebels kill many in Bangui church attack]. ''BBC''. Retrieved 2014-05-30. In July 2014, the government of [[Uganda]] declared that it was at war with Seleka accusing them of forcing civilians to give food and medicine to the [[Lords Resistance Army]] and of trading ivory and minerals with them. Seleka denied the accusation.[https://news.yahoo.com/uganda-clashes-central-africa-republics-seleka-rebels-114632620.html Yahoo News: "Uganda says Seleka now its enemy as it hunts LRA in Central African Republic" By Elias Biryabarema and Crispin Dembassa-Kette] July 1, 2014 Seleka leader Abdoulaye Issene said in an interview that: "We have killed, murdered and violated, but what happenend, happened".http://www.unhcr.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/refdaily?pass=52fc6fbd5&id=53bf786c8http://www.unhcr.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/refdaily?pass=52fc6fbd5&date=2014-07-11&cat=Africa On November 9, 2015, armed men cut the throats of 10 people in the village of [[Ndassima]] before carrying out an overnight attack nearby in [[Mala, Central African Republic|Mala]]. Local administrator Yves Mbetigaza said "They came from two places, some from Bambari and others from Mbres." While a report on national radio described the attackers only as armed members of the [[Fula people|Fula]] ethnic group (in {{lang-fr|Peul}}), Mbetigaza said they were Seleka fighters, adding that eight villagers were kidnapped in Mala and dozens of others were missing. On November 12, six hunters were killed in the village of [[Bandambou]].[https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/13/us-centralafrica-violence-idUSKCN0T21S120151113#O3I1uJmw1ZWMbUdd.99 At least 22 dead in Central African Republic village attacks]. Nov 13, 2015. Reuters. Retrieved 2015-11-17. On December 3, 2015, the Seleka armed men killed eight civilians at a camp for displaced people and wounded one U.N. peacekeeper, just days after the pope visited the capital. The attacks took place at Ngakobo, about 60 km (40 miles) south of the central town of Bambari.[https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-centralafrica-attacks/eight-killed-in-central-african-republic-days-after-popes-visit-idUKKBN0TN23C20151204 Eight killed in Central African Republic days after pope's visit]. December 4, 2015. ''Reuters''. Retrieved 2017-12-27. Seleka often contends that mercenaries are to blame for the abuses. It is reported that official Seleka fighters are called for help to protect against mobs of ex-Seleka fighter. ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==References== {{refbegin}} *{{Cite press release | [[Asmik Ace]] }} | released = {{Film date|2017|10|21}} | runtime = 100 minutes | country = Japan | language = Japanese | budget = | gross = {{USD|8.6 million}}{{cite web|script-title= Psychic Kusuo|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&wk=2017W43&id=_fPSYCHICKUSUO01|website=Box Office Mojo|accessdate= June 14, 2018}} }} {{Nihongo|'''''The Disastrous Life of Saiki K.'''''|斉木楠雄のΨ難|Saiki Kusuo no Sai-nan|lead=yes}} is a [[science fiction|sci-fi]] [[comedy film|comedy]] film adaptation of the [[The Disastrous Life of Saiki K.|manga series by Shūichi Asō]], directed by Yuichi Fukuda. Starring [[Kento Yamazaki]], [[Ryo Yoshizawa]] and [[Kanna Hashimoto]] at [[Columbia Pictures]] ([[Sony Pictures Entertainment Japan]]) and [[Asmik Ace]]. Released on October 21, 2017.{{cite news|url=http://natalie.mu/eiga/news/196418|title=山崎賢人が「斉木楠雄のΨ難」で主演、監督は「銀魂」も手がける福田雄一|newspaper=映画ナタリー|accessdate=2016-08-01|date=2016-08-01}} It was the first Sony Pictures Japanese film that was not distributed by [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group#Sony Pictures Releasing|Sony Pictures Releasing]] and was also the first Sony Pictures Japanese film to be distributed by Columbia Pictures. ==Plot== Kusuo Saiki ([[Kento Yamazaki]]) is a 16-year-old high school student. He was born with lots of powers, including telepathy and telekinesis. This may sound cool, but, according to Kusuo's experience, super powers are not as good as we imagine. He tries to live a normal life, despite having a power that upsets him. Kusuo Saiki now tries to keep a distance from others to hide his psychic abilities, but his classmates with distinct individuality gather under Kusuo. ==Cast== * [[Kento Yamazaki]] as Kusuo Saikihttps://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-03-14/live-action-the-disastrous-life-of-saiki-k-film-reveals-cast-visuals-teaser-video/.113431 * [[Ryo Yoshizawa]] as Shun Kaidō * [[Kanna Hashimoto]] as Kokomi Teruhashi * [[Hirofumi Arai]] as Riki Nendō * Hideyuki Kasahara as Kineshi Hairo * [[Kento Kaku]] as Aren Kuboyasu * [[Tsuyoshi Muro]] as Uryoku Chōno * [[Jiro Sato (actor)|Jiro Sato]] as Pinsuke Kanda * [[Seiichi Tanabe]] as Kuniharu Saikihttps://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-05-18/live-action-the-disastrous-life-of-saiki-k-film-adds-seiichi-tanabe-yuki-uchida-to-cast/.116249 * [[Yuki Uchida]] as Kurumi Saiki ==Reception== This film grossed {{USD|8.6 million}} at the Japanese box office. Rachel Cheung of ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' found the film to be overacted: "It may be funny for the first time, and maybe the second, that the sweet 19-year-old actress Hashimoto imitates the exaggerated facial expressions of her anime character; but when it happens for the 10th time, it becomes quite boring, if not irritating."{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/culture/film-tv/article/2138256/psychic-kusuo-film-review-disastrous-adaptation-manga-disastrous|title=Psychic Kusuo review: Gintama director’s latest is a disaster|author=|date=|website=scmp.com|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://saikikusuo-movie.jp/}} {{ja icon}} * {{IMDb title|tt4773438}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Disastrous Life Of Saiki K., The (film)}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:2010s comedy films]] [[Category:2010s comedy science fiction films]] [[Category:2010s science fiction films]] [[Category:Alien invasions in films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:Films about NASA]] [[Category:Films about space programs]] [[Category:Films about technology]] [[Category:Films set in Japan]] [[Category:Films set in outer space]] [[Category:Films about psychic powers]] [[Category:Films set in Tokyo]] [[Category:Government in fiction]] [[Category:Japanese films]] [[Category:Japanese-language films]] [[Category:Japanese fantasy films]] [[Category:Japanese comedy films]] [[Category:Japanese science fiction films]] [[Category:Manga adapted into films]] [[Category:Mythology in popular culture]] [[Category:Japanese science fiction films]] [[Category:Supernatural anime and manga]] {{2010s-comedy-film-stub}} {{2010s-Japan-film-stub}}
